PN.content:
Please identify the "Property Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: The polymer PDTP-DT2BT exhibits the highest PCE of 3.12% , ascribed to the largest J SC = 11.43 mA cm^-2 with a slightly lower V OC of 0.54 V and a slightly higher FF of 0.57 than the other polymers.

Let's think step by step.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| PCE |
| J SC |
| V OC |
| FF |

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material property" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| PCE |
| J SC |
| V OC |

The following entities do not clearly refer to "Material property":

* "PCE" (not a material property, but rather a measure of the performance of a solar cell)
* "FF" (not a material property, but rather a measure of the fill factor of a solar cell)

The valid entities that clearly refer to material properties are:

* "J SC" (short for "junction solar cell", which is a type of solar cell)
* "V OC" (short for "open-circuit voltage", which is a material property of a solar cell)

Please identify the "Property Value" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: The polymer PDTP-DT2BT exhibits the highest PCE of 3.12% , ascribed to the largest J SC = 11.43 mA cm^-2 with a slightly lower V OC of 0.54 V and a slightly higher FF of 0.57 than the other polymers.

Let's think step by step.

| --- | --- |

| J SC | 11.43 mA cm^-2 |
| V OC | 0.54 V |
| FF | 0.57 |

Note that "PCE" stands for "power conversion efficiency", "J SC" stands for "short-circuit current density", "V OC" stands for "open-circuit voltage", and "FF" stands for "fill factor".
